caption: Fashion in Peru! Memories of a wonderful assignment for Nikon Latam, working in the urban areas of Lima and the Paracas Peninsula, which is sparse, forbidding and beautiful. Grateful to have worked with three incredibly talented women (@claudiamariaca, @lafefacox, @fvilogron) in front of the camera. Just ran a pic of Claudia and there were wonderful reactions and lots of questions. The whole series I worked quite simply, most of the time. A lot of one-light pictures. @profoto light shapers and sources, mostly B1X. At 500 watt seconds, I occasionally put two of those units into the same light shaper, to fight back against the harsh desert light. Beauty dishes, umbrellas, large soft boxes, we pretty much used it all, including grip and 12x12 silks provided by the peerless production company, @lacasa_films. So much fun to work with that talented team! Closing night I still remember Rafi‚Äôs homemade pizza üòä LaCasa Films, Claudia, Fefa and Francesca made the job easy at camera with their professionalism, energy and enthusiasm. Big thanks all around, especially to my studio team. A memorable assignment! #fashionphotography #onlocationphotography #NikonD810 #NikonAmbassador Checkout the Behind-the-Scenes video- LINKIN BIO‚¨ÜÔ∏è

A Saturday morning stroll! The lovely @claudiamariaca walks the starkly beautiful Paracas Desert. We‚Äôve worked together a couple of times, in Peru and in Vegas. Always amazing in front of the lens. Nikon D810 with a 70-200mm lens, from a fashion project a few years ago. The beauty and benefit of one big light source! @profoto B1-X through a 4‚Äô RFI Octa, fitted with a fabric grid. The grid helps keep light splash off the road in the foreground of the picture, which is always a dead bang giveaway as to where you put the light. Big light even from a distance is wonderful. Telephoto gives the endless road compression and a shape. And Claudia conveys to the scene a casual, nonchalant elegance.
As in ‚ÄúI always walk on abandoned desert roads in an evening gown, doesn‚Äôt everyone?‚Äù I believe the French give it the term insouciance. üòÄ

#saturday #picoftheday @NikonUSA¬†¬†#NikonPro #NikonAmbassador #NikonD810¬†#claudiamariaca

Nature abounds. Just back from another trip to the Amazon Rainforest in Ecuador, a truly astonishing place to photograph. Our group had the benefit and wonder of staying at LaSelva Lodge, a jewel of an ecolodge nestled in the heart of the jungle. Perched on a lagoon, the wild nature of the jungle is literally at your doorstep every day. Beautiful rooms, wonderful food, and an array of incredibly knowledgeable guides who lead you through a week of discovery with certainty and expertise. A terrific week. Thanks to all in our group, hardy travelers all, who made lovely images. The pic of this squirrel monkey was made with the @nikonusa Z 9 with the 180-600 f/6.3, ISO 6400 at the edge of dusk, hand-held from a canoe. Shutter speed was at 1/640th.  The new construction of Nikon‚Äôs long glass tremendously aids in hand holding, especially from an unstable platform. Many thanks to @fancygirlstreetboy and @ari_espay for putting together an amazing trip, as always. And to  @tamaralackey for her wonderful teaching and friendship.

#ThursdayThoughts #travelphotography #nikonambassador #nikonpro #nikonz9 #picoftheday #luxuryjunglelodge @laselvaecolodge Link: laselvajunglelodge.com

Memories in a mirror. At the Blue Bar at the Algonquin Hotel, a lovely lady checks her makeup. Part of a Noir series I created for Nikon, using wireless Speedlight technology. The Blue Bar is legendary, and visually fits well with the mood of noir mystery. This series of images took us from New York to New Mexico, to the Blue Swallow Motel on Rt. 66 in Tucumcari. Our model is the beautiful Laetitia, on Instagram as the noted DJ @djdevaler. All done with @nikonusa SB-5000 Speedlights. This set at the Blue Bar was just the beginning of the story of this lady of mystery. 

Nikon D5 w 85mm f/1.8 lens. Blending the flash with the mood of the bar.
#thursdaythoughts #throwbackthursday @samanthabrownstyle @northorchard @nikonusa #nikonambassador #nikonpro

I noticed yesterday was #internationaltutuday. Have always loved oddness, or what John Loengard, the DOP at LIFE, and a powerful mentor, used to refer to as ‚Äúpeculiarity.‚Äù Being peculiar when behind the camera is an asset, I believe. So, I spin notions up in my head. Created this scene in Havana, which is one of the most congenial and beautiful places, ever. And the dance community is vibrant and astonishingly talented. 

#internationaltutuday #saturdaymorning #NikonD850 #NikonAmbassador #NikonPro @nikonusa #dance #ballet

A face with character. A face the light from the window simply embraces in eloquent fashion with the NIKKOR Z 58mm f/0.95 S NOCT. Simple is often best, especially when someone‚Äôs life and character speak so loudly and their life‚Äôs history is written on their face. Topics for today here at @imagingusa - Managing Light and Dynamic Portraiture. #sundaymorning #portraitphotography #nikonambassador #nikonpro #nikkorz58mm #nikonz7 @nikonusa #imagingusa2024

Shooting for Sports Illustrated was an adventure. Working, improbably, for the biggest, best, most powerful sports mag in the world. I say improbable as I was never much of a sideline, action-style photog. How could I be? At any major sports event, Sports Illustrated could populate any competition pitch in the world with photogs who need no explanation or introduction. Zimmerman, Leifer, Cooke, Drake, Iooss, Kluetmeier, Frakes, Iacono, Tiedemann, Biever, Millan - to name a few! Photogs with smarts, experience, knowledge of the game being covered, and an almost preternatural ability to be in the right place, with the right lens, at the critical moments of a contest. 
I was asked to become a contract photographer for SI in 1985. I was a feature guy, shooting the off-the-field stuff, the portraits, the concept-driven, illustrative spread type of photos that might lead a section or a major story. It was heady stuff, as SI had money to burn and the kind of powerful sway that would make even the most obnoxious sports agent return your calls. 
It was a great magazine, filled with writing that was often beautifully reflective and evocative, and the kind of still photos that made readers still want to pick up the magazine and devour visuals about a game that they had already seen. Can you imagine? It was like a Ron Howard movie every week, making a riveting story out of a game where everybody already knew who won. The power of good stories, in words and pictures, flowed from its pages. 
¬†
And after nearly 70 years of publishing, now gone‚Ä¶..

Ray James, who occupies a place of honor in the world of boxing, goes by the moniker @artistrayjames on Instagram. And indeed he is. It was such a pleasure photographing this articulate, physically amazing artist and athlete. Good pic for Monday Motivation! As we plunge into the new year, all of us with our resolutions, hopefully still intact! Photographed him throughout a day in a warehouse in upstate NY. Simply followed the natural light until stopping here, where it sliced through the windows at a low angle, beautifully warm and slashing, matching Ray‚Äôs physique.

@artistrayjames ¬†#motivationmonday #picoftheday #mondaymorning #nikonambassador #NikonZ7¬†@nikonusa Fun BTS over on our YT channel!

The lavender fields in the south of France are stunningly beautiful and arrayed, wonderfully, as if the farmers had photographers in mind. Beautifully linear, graphic rows of astonishing color greet the eye. Designed equally well for long or wide glass. In this instance, shot with the Nikkor 200-500mm on a Nikon D850, the compression of the long glass makes the fields seem endless, which, in reality, they pretty much are. Gorgeous sunlight graced us on this particular morning. We were shooting commercially, so we had obtained permission for the field, paid a fee, signed a property release. Our lovely young model was the daughter of our location producer, also a wonderful occurrence. But‚Ä¶the best part ‚òïÔ∏èü•Æ! We had on location catering for the crew. French bread and croissants, coffee, fruit, etc. Great memory out there in the fields of France. 

#saturdaymorning #portraitphotography #nikonambassador #nikonnofilter @nikonusa #lavenderfields

Hoping to make a splash in 24? üòÄNate Newton, then of the Dallas Cowboys, certainly did. Shot on medium format film for Sports Illustrated in the 90‚Äôs, for a story concentrating on offensive lineman, who are the biggest guys on the field. Newton was part of the legendary ‚ÄúWall of Dallas‚Äù a famed front line. He was also pretty well known for his girth, tipping the scales at maybe, like, 330 or so. Which I did not take into account on the first of these diving board leaps as I was balancing a Mamiya RZ67 Pro with a motor drive and a 50mm lens on a little float type thing, such as one would get at Walmart. Designed for a kid, not the pool based tidal wave Nate caused when he hit the water. Major water over the camera and me. Luckily, I had a second camera, and as I remember we put the soaked camera down on the deck, in the Dallas August sun, and that revived it. Thankfully it wasn‚Äôt fully dunked! But we went back to work, got this and some other images. Nate was great to work with.

#wednesdaywisdom #waybackwednesday #picoftheday #filmphotography

Looking to 24! And fitness is on a lot of folk‚Äôs minds as New Year‚Äôs resolutions abound. One of the most amazing, talented and supremely fit people I ever photographed was Gabby Reece. Pro volleyball player of legendary status, fitness coach, model, author, podcaster. Shot this back in film days, medium format. The notion of strength I tried to conjure by having a huge prop volleyball made and to have her support it, Atlas-like. We got the ball to the desert and inflated it, and it was way too shiny and new. So the crew pretty much chipped in a bunch of our water to make a mud puddle on the parched turf and we then rolled the ball around in it. Location improv! Another significant improvisation was to take two hi-rollers off to the side and run hi strength monofilament fishing line to little loops that had been built into the prop ball. Barely visible even in the original negatives. Never published this frame before, always went with the color, but the B&W I think actually accentuates Gabby‚Äôs strength. LMK what you think. Highly recommend her podcast BTW. Also, she is married to monster wave surfer Laird Hamilton who is legendary himself. Together they are a font of fitness and excellence wisdom. 

#saturdaymorning #picoftheday #athlete #fitnessgoals #monochrome
